text:
When a new session is created like this:

HttpSession sesion=request.getSession(true);

If just after that line whe do the following:

System.out.println(request.isRequestedSessionIdValid());

The result we get is "false", even though the session has been created for that 
request. I've checked that sesion!=null and sesion.getId()!=null, so it seems a 
problem whith the isRequestedSessionIdValid() method...

Thanks

text:
The incoming request did not provide a valid session id. So returning false is
acceptable.

Patrick Holthuizen wrote: > Why is it valid? The API specs state that it should return true if the > request holds an id for a valid session and I think it should after > creating one. No, since a session has been *created* in your case, the request does not hold the id of a valid session. Instead, the newly created session will be reflected in the response. Notice that the word "requested" in the method name refers to a session *requested and specified by the client*. For example, HttpServletRequest.getRequestedSessionId() has this: * If the client did not specify a session ID, this method returns * null. It may be worth adding a similar comment to isRequestedSessionIdValid(), as follows: * If the client did not specify a session ID, this method returns * false.
